info.title: Crosshair API
info.description:
## Search & Intelligence Platform

A comprehensive OSINT and search API for security research, threat intelligence, and data collection.

### Core Capabilities

| Category | Features |
|----------|----------|
| **Search** | 70+ engines, images, videos, news, academic |
| **Intelligence** | DNS, WHOIS, TLS, threat feeds, IP reputation |
| **Content** | URL extraction, PDF parsing, screenshot capture |
| **Security** | Vulnerability scanning, SIGMA/YARA rules |
| **Automation** | Monitors, webhooks, scheduled jobs |
| **Data Collection** | Web crawlers, spider generation, Telegram OSINT |

### API Design
- **RESTful**: Standard HTTP methods and status codes
- **Versioned**: All endpoints prefixed with `/v1/`
- **Consistent**: Standardized response envelopes
- **Traceable**: Request ID headers for debugging

### Authentication
Most endpoints are open. Rate-limited endpoints accept `X-API-Key` header.

### Response Format
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "data": { ... },
  "meta": { "request_id": "...", "cached": false }
}
```

get.description:
Kubernetes liveness probe.

Fast check that returns immediately. No dependency checks.
Used to detect if the process is alive.

Kubernetes readiness probe.

Checks critical dependencies (Valkey, SearXNG).
Returns 503 if not ready to accept traffic.

Full health check with all dependencies.

Returns detailed status of all services:
- API (uptime)
- SearXNG (search engine)
- Valkey (cache)
- Selectors service (browser automation)
- MinerU (document processing)

API version information.

Returns current API version and build info.

Get cache statistics.

Returns memory usage, key counts, and uptime.

delete.description:
Clear cached search results.

Only allows clearing search:* keys for safety.

get.description:
Execute a web search with optional NLP enrichment.

Supports Google dork syntax:
- `site:example.com` - limit to domain
- `filetype:pdf` - specific file types
- `intitle:"phrase"` - words in title
- `"exact phrase"` - exact match
- `-exclude` - exclude terms

Fallback: If SearXNG returns no results or is blocked, automatically falls back
to Camoufox browser-based search (Google/Bing) with anti-detection.

Returns paginated results with standardized response envelope.

parameters.name: use_browser

schema.description: Force Camoufox browser fallback (bypasses bot detection)
schema.title: Use Browser

parameters.description: Force Camoufox browser fallback (bypasses bot detection)

get.description:
Search for images across multiple engines.

Returns image URLs, thumbnails, and source information.
Search for videos across YouTube, Vimeo, and other platforms.

Search for news articles across multiple sources.

Supports time-based filtering for recent news.

parameters.name: freshness

schema.description: Time range: day, week, month, year
schema.title: Freshness

parameters.description: Time range: day, week, month, year

get.description: Get search suggestions/autocomplete for a partial query.

Search academic papers and scholarly content.

Uses academic-focused search engines (Google Scholar, arXiv, PubMed, etc.).

Search for products across shopping engines.

Returns product listings with prices, merchants, and availability.
Supports Schema.org Product data where available.

Fallback strategy:
1. SearXNG shopping category engines (eBay, Geizhals, etc.)
2. General search with site: operators for major shopping sites
3. Camoufox browser scraping (Amazon, eBay, Google Shopping) - bypasses bot detection

Search with automatic topic clustering.

Groups search results by topic using semantic embeddings and clustering.
Each result includes `cluster_id` and `cluster_label` fields.

Clustering methods:
- `hdbscan`: Density-based clustering (automatic cluster count, handles outliers)
- `kmeans`: K-means clustering (fixed cluster count, fast)

Returns results organized by topic cluster.

Search for music across streaming platforms.

Engines: Bandcamp, SoundCloud, Deezer, YouTube Music, Mixcloud, Genius, etc.

Search for files and downloads.

Engines: Anna's Archive, PirateBay, Kickass, App Stores, etc.

Search across social media platforms.

Engines: Reddit, Mastodon, Lemmy (posts, comments, communities, users).

Search code repositories and ML models.

Engines: GitHub, GitLab, Codeberg, Sourcehut, HuggingFace (models, datasets, spaces), Ollama.

Search for locations and places.

Engines: OpenStreetMap, Apple Maps, Photon geocoder.

Search the Tor network (.onion sites) safely and anonymously.

**Privacy Features:**
- All queries routed through Tor SOCKS5h proxy (DNS leak safe)
- No IP address exposure to .onion sites
- Results filtered by Ahmia's blacklist (removes harmful content)

**Engines:**
- Ahmia: Tor Project-endorsed search engine (filters illegal content)
- Torch: One of the oldest .onion search engines

**Note:** Tor searches are slower (10-30s) due to onion routing latency.
Results may include .onion URLs that require Tor Browser to access.

**Security Warning:** Exercise caution when visiting .onion links.

Search technical and programming resources.

**Engines:**
- Stack Overflow, Stack Exchange, SuperUser
- GitHub Gist, GitLab snippets
- Hacker News, Lobsters
- MDN Web Docs, DevDocs
- Ask Ubuntu, Unix & Linux

Ideal for: code examples, error messages, technical documentation,
programming Q&A, developer tools.

Search package registries and software repositories.

**Engines:**
- PyPI (Python)
- npm (JavaScript/Node.js)
- crates.io (Rust)
- Docker Hub (containers)
- Packagist (PHP/Composer)

Returns package metadata including version, description, and registry source.

Search scientific databases and resources.

**Engines:**
- Wolfram Alpha (computational)
- PubMed (biomedical)
- arXiv (preprints)
- Semantic Scholar
- Science.gov

**Difference from /scholar:**
- /scholar focuses on academic papers and citations
- /science includes computational answers, datasets, and broader scientific resources

Search Q&A platforms for questions and answers.

**Engines:**
- Stack Exchange network (all sites)
- Quora
- Reddit (Q&A subreddits)
- Yahoo Answers archive
- Ask.com

Ideal for: How-to questions, troubleshooting, opinions, recommendations.

Search for torrents across multiple trackers.

**Engines:**
- PirateBay, 1337x, Kickass, BTDigg
- Nyaa (anime), TokyoToshokan
- SolidTorrents, BT4G

**Returns:**
- Magnet links for direct download
- Seeder/leecher counts
- File sizes

**Note:** For legal content only. Respect copyright laws.

Search for ebooks and digital books.

**Engines:**
- Anna's Archive (largest shadow library)
- Library Genesis (LibGen)
- Z-Library

**Returns:**
- Book titles, authors
- File formats (PDF, EPUB, MOBI)
- Download links

Ideal for: textbooks, technical books, research papers, fiction.

Search for movies and TV shows.

**Engines:**
- IMDB (ratings, cast, info)
- Moviepilot, SensCritique
- Rottentomatoes

**Returns:**
- Movie titles, years
- Ratings and reviews
- Cast and crew info

Search for mobile and desktop applications.

**Engines:**
- Google Play Store (Android)
- Apple App Store (iOS)
- F-Droid (open source Android)
- APK Mirror (Android APKs)

**Returns:**
- App names and descriptions
- Store links
- Platform information

post.description:
Extract full article text and metadata from a URL.

Supports HTML pages and PDFs.

Queue batch URL extraction as an async job.

Returns immediately with job_id. Poll /v1/jobs/{job_id} for status.
Optional webhook callback when complete.

get.description:
Get screenshot URLs for a webpage using external services.

Returns URLs to multiple screenshot services.

Extract XPath and CSS selectors from a webpage.

Uses browser automation to find elements with quality-rated selectors.
Supports semantic search to find specific elements (e.g., "login button").

Proxies to internal selectors service for process isolation.

Convert a webpage to clean markdown.

Uses reader-lm model via Ollama for conversion.
Falls back to cleaned HTML text if unavailable.

post.description:
Anonymize PII (Personally Identifiable Information) in text.

Uses Microsoft Presidio for detection and anonymization.

Supported operators:
- replace: Replace with <ENTITY_TYPE> placeholder (default)
- redact: Remove completely
- mask: Partial masking (e.g., ****@email.com)
- hash: SHA256 hash
- keep: Don't anonymize this entity type

Example request:
```json
{
    "text": "John Smith's email is john@example.com",
    "default_operator": "replace",
    "entities": ["EMAIL_ADDRESS", "PERSON"],
    "score_threshold": 0.5
}
```

Example response:
```json
{
    "success": true,
    "data": {
        "text": "<PERSON>'s email is <EMAIL_ADDRESS>",
        "entities_detected": 2,
        "entity_counts": {"PERSON": 1, "EMAIL_ADDRESS": 1}
    }
}
```

Extract content from a URL and anonymize any PII.

Combines content extraction with PII anonymization in a single request.

Example request:
```json
{
    "url": "https://example.com/article",
    "default_operator": "replace",
    "max_chars": 10000
}
```

get.description:
List all supported PII entity types.

Returns entity type names, descriptions, and examples.

Supported entity types include:
- PERSON: Full person names
- EMAIL_ADDRESS: Email addresses
- PHONE_NUMBER: Phone numbers
- US_SSN: US Social Security Numbers
- CREDIT_CARD: Credit card numbers
- IP_ADDRESS: IPv4/IPv6 addresses
- And more...

Specialized search for data breach notifications.

Automatically searches relevant sources like state AG offices,
SEC filings, and news sources.

Perform DNS lookup for a domain.

Returns A records, aliases, and hostname information.

Get WHOIS information for a domain.

Returns registration details, nameservers, and dates.

Get comprehensive intelligence about a domain.

Includes DNS records, HTTP headers, and indexed pages.

Search for a username across social media platforms.

Returns potential profile matches from various platforms.

Enumerate subdomains for a domain.

Uses search engine data to discover subdomains.

Extract entity relationship graph from search results.

Performs a search and extracts named entities (people, organizations,
locations, etc.) from the results. Returns a graph structure showing
entities and their co-occurrence relationships.

The graph can be visualized using libraries like D3.js, vis.js, or cytoscape.

Response includes:
- `nodes`: Entity nodes with id, label, count, and description
- `edges`: Relationships between entities with source, target, and weight
- `total_entities`: Total unique entities found
- `total_relationships`: Total relationships found

parameters.name: limit

schema.description: Number of search results to analyze
schema.title: Limit

parameters.description: Number of search results to analyze

get.description:
Detect technologies used by a website.

Analyzes HTTP headers, meta tags, URL patterns, scripts, and CSS
to identify CMS, frameworks, libraries, servers, and other technologies.

No external APIs required - all detection is done locally.

Analyze security headers and provide a security score.

Checks for important security headers like:
- Content-Security-Policy (XSS protection)
- Strict-Transport-Security (HTTPS enforcement)
- X-Frame-Options (clickjacking protection)
- X-Content-Type-Options (MIME sniffing)
- Referrer-Policy (information leakage)
- Permissions-Policy (feature restrictions)

Returns a score (0-100) and letter grade (A+ to F).

No external APIs required.

Get TLS/SSL certificate and connection information.

Returns certificate details including:
- Subject and issuer
- Validity dates and expiration status
- Subject Alternative Names (SAN)
- Key size and algorithm
- TLS version and cipher suite
- Security issues (weak ciphers, expiring cert, etc.)

No external APIs required.

parameters.name: domain

schema.description: Domain to get TLS info for
schema.title: Domain

parameters.description: Domain to get TLS info for

get.description:
Aggregate threat intelligence from multiple external APIs.

Checks URL/domain against:
- VirusTotal (malware scanning)
- Google Safe Browsing (phishing/malware)
- AbuseIPDB (IP reputation)
- Shodan (IP intelligence)
- Hybrid Analysis (malware sandbox)

**Requires API keys** configured in environment:
- VIRUSTOTAL_API_KEY
- GOOGLE_SAFE_BROWSING_KEY
- ABUSEIPDB_API_KEY
- SHODAN_API_KEY
- HYBRID_ANALYSIS_API_KEY

Sources without keys will be skipped gracefully.

Get IP address reputation and geolocation.

Returns:
- IP version and private/public status
- Geolocation (country, region, city)
- Abuse reports and confidence score
- Open ports and services (via Shodan)
- Known vulnerabilities
- Reverse DNS
- ASN and ISP information

**Requires API keys** for full data:
- ABUSEIPDB_API_KEY (abuse reports)
- SHODAN_API_KEY (ports, services, vulns)

Sources without keys will be skipped gracefully.

Get complete TLS fingerprint with JARM and JA3S.

Returns:
- **JARM**: Active server fingerprint (62 chars) from 10 TLS probes
- **JA3S**: Server response fingerprint (MD5 hash)
- **TLS version**: Negotiated TLS version
- **Cipher suite**: Negotiated cipher
- **Identification**: Known service match if found

JARM can identify:
- CDNs (Cloudflare, Akamai, Fastly)
- Web servers (Nginx, Apache)
- Load balancers (AWS ELB)
- Malware C2 (Cobalt Strike, Metasploit)

No external APIs required.

Get JARM fingerprint for a TLS server.

JARM is an active TLS server fingerprinting tool developed by Salesforce.
It sends 10 specially crafted TLS Client Hello packets and creates a
62-character fingerprint from the server's responses.

The first 30 characters represent cipher/TLS version choices.
The remaining 32 characters are a SHA256 hash of extensions.

JARM fingerprints are useful for:
- Identifying server software and configurations
- Detecting malware C2 servers (Cobalt Strike, Metasploit)
- Tracking infrastructure across IP changes
- Identifying CDNs and load balancers

No external APIs required.

Get JA3S fingerprint for a TLS server.

JA3S fingerprints the server's TLS ServerHello response.
Format: TLSVersion,CipherSuite,Extensions

The fingerprint is MD5 hashed for easy comparison.

JA3S is passive (captures actual negotiation) vs JARM which is active.
Combined with client JA3, it creates a unique client-server fingerprint.

No external APIs required.

Look up a JARM fingerprint in the known fingerprint database.

Returns identification information if the fingerprint matches
a known service, CDN, or malware signature.

The database includes fingerprints for:
- CDNs: Cloudflare, Akamai, Fastly
- Web servers: Nginx, Apache
- Load balancers: AWS ELB, Azure
- Malware C2: Cobalt Strike, Metasploit

No external APIs required.

Get JA4 fingerprint for a TLS connection.

JA4 is the next-generation TLS fingerprinting standard from FoxIO,
designed to replace JA3 with better resistance to randomization.

Format: [protocol][version][sni][ciphers][extensions][alpn]_[cipher_hash]_[ext_hash]
Example: t13d1516h2_8daaf6152771_e5627efa2ab1

Components:
- Protocol: t (TLS), q (QUIC), d (DTLS)
- Version: 13 (TLS 1.3), 12 (TLS 1.2), etc.
- SNI: d (domain) or i (IP)
- Cipher/Extension counts
- ALPN first+last chars
- SHA256 hashes (truncated to 12 chars)

No external APIs required.

Get JA4S (server) fingerprint.

JA4S fingerprints the TLS server's response, similar to JA3S but
using the improved JA4 methodology from FoxIO.

Format: [protocol][version][ext_count][alpn]_[cipher]_[ext_hash]

This fingerprint identifies the server's TLS configuration and
can be used to identify server software and configurations.

No external APIs required.

Search for hosts using Censys Search Language.

Example queries:
- `services.http.response.html_title: "Login"`
- `services.port: 443 AND location.country: US`
- `services.software.product: nginx`

**Requires API credentials:**
- CENSYS_API_ID
- CENSYS_API_SECRET

See https://search.censys.io/search/language for query syntax.

parameters.name: virtual_hosts

schema.description: Virtual host handling: EXCLUDE, INCLUDE, ONLY
schema.title: Virtual Hosts

parameters.description: Virtual host handling: EXCLUDE, INCLUDE, ONLY

get.description:
Get detailed host information from Censys.

Returns comprehensive data including:
- Open ports and services
- TLS certificates
- HTTP response data
- Operating system detection
- Autonomous system information

**Requires API credentials:**
- CENSYS_API_ID
- CENSYS_API_SECRET

Search SSL/TLS certificates in Censys database.

Search across 15B+ certificate records.

Example queries:
- `parsed.subject.common_name: example.com`
- `parsed.issuer.organization: "Let's Encrypt"`
- `parsed.validity.end: [now TO now+30d]`

**Requires API credentials:**
- CENSYS_API_ID
- CENSYS_API_SECRET

Find hosts presenting a specific certificate.

Args:
    fingerprint: SHA-256 fingerprint of the certificate

Useful for:
- Finding all servers using the same certificate
- Certificate transparency investigation
- Infrastructure mapping

**Requires API credentials:**
- CENSYS_API_ID
- CENSYS_API_SECRET

Search CVEs using Vulners database.

Lucene-style query syntax:
- `apache` - Simple keyword search
- `type:cve AND cvss3.cvssV3.baseScore:>=9` - Critical CVEs
- `title:*f5* AND bulletinFamily:exploit` - F5 exploits

**Requires API key:**
- VULNERS_API_KEY

Search for exploits in Vulners database.

Returns exploit code, metasploit modules, and proof-of-concepts.

**Requires API key:**
- VULNERS_API_KEY

Get detailed CVE information from Vulners.

Returns:
- CVE description
- CVSS scores (v2 and v3)
- Affected products/versions
- References and advisories
- Related exploits

**Requires API key:**
- VULNERS_API_KEY

Find exploits for a specific CVE.

Returns available exploit code, metasploit modules, and PoCs
that reference this CVE.

**Requires API key:**
- VULNERS_API_KEY

Search vulnerabilities by product/version.

Find known vulnerabilities affecting a specific software product.

Examples:
- `/vulners/product?product=apache&version=2.4.49`
- `/vulners/product?product=nginx&severity=CRITICAL`

**Requires API key:**
- VULNERS_API_KEY

Get SSL Labs API status and limits.

Returns:
- Engine version
- Maximum concurrent assessments
- Current assessment count
- API message of the day

No API key required.

Start or retrieve SSL/TLS analysis.

Note: Full analysis takes 60+ seconds per endpoint.
Use from_cache=true for faster results.

Status values:
- DNS: Resolving domain
- IN_PROGRESS: Analysis running
- READY: Analysis complete
- ERROR: Analysis failed

No API key required (but rate limited).

post.description:
Start analysis and wait for completion.

This is a blocking call that polls until the analysis is complete
or times out. For production use, prefer the async analyze endpoint.

Typical analysis takes 60-120 seconds.

No API key required (but rate limited).

get.description:
Get SSL grade summary from cache.

Returns simplified grade information:
- Overall grade (A+ to F)
- Per-endpoint grades
- Vulnerability flags
- Basic scoring

Uses cached data only - won't start new analysis.
For fresh results, use /ssllabs/analyze first.

No API key required.

Check URL against abuse.ch URLhaus database.

URLhaus is a project of abuse.ch with the goal of sharing
malicious URLs that are being used for malware distribution.

No API key required (free service).

Check host against abuse.ch URLhaus database.

Returns all malicious URLs associated with the host.

No API key required (free service).

Get recent malicious URLs from URLhaus feed.

Returns the most recently added malicious URLs.

No API key required (free service).

Look up file hash in Malware Bazaar database.

Malware Bazaar is a project from abuse.ch with the goal of
sharing malware samples with the infosec community.

No API key required (free service).

Search Malware Bazaar samples by tag.

Common tags: ransomware, trojan, banker, stealer, rat, etc.

No API key required (free service).

Search Malware Bazaar samples by malware signature/family.

Returns samples matching the malware family name.

No API key required (free service).

Get recent malware samples from Malware Bazaar.

Returns the most recently uploaded samples.

No API key required (free service).

post.description:
Look up IOC in ThreatFox database.

ThreatFox is a free platform from abuse.ch for sharing
indicators of compromise (IOCs) associated with malware.

Supports: URLs, domains, IP:port, file hashes.

Request body:
```json
{"ioc": "http://example.com/malware.exe"}
```

No API key required (free service).

get.description:
Search ThreatFox by malware family.

Returns IOCs associated with the specified malware.

No API key required (free service).

Get recent IOCs from ThreatFox.

Returns IOCs added within the specified time window.

No API key required (free service).

Look up IP in GreyNoise database.

GreyNoise analyzes internet-wide scan and attack traffic.
It categorizes IPs as:
- **noise**: Background internet scanning
- **riot**: Benign services (CDNs, cloud providers)
- **malicious**: Known malicious activity
- **benign**: Known safe sources
- **unknown**: Not enough data

Uses Community API (free tier, rate limited).

Check if IP is in GreyNoise RIOT database.

RIOT (Rule It Out) contains IPs belonging to:
- Cloud providers (AWS, GCP, Azure)
- CDNs (Cloudflare, Akamai, Fastly)
- Security scanners (Shodan, Censys)
- Other benign services

Useful for reducing false positives in security alerts.

Quick noise check for an IP.

Faster than full lookup. Only returns whether the IP
is seen generating noise on the internet.

Look up IP indicator in AlienVault OTX.

Returns pulses (threat reports) that reference this IP.

**Requires OTX_API_KEY** (free registration at alienvault.com).

Look up domain indicator in AlienVault OTX.

Returns pulses (threat reports) that reference this domain.

**Requires OTX_API_KEY** (free registration at alienvault.com).

Look up file hash indicator in AlienVault OTX.

Returns pulses (threat reports) that reference this hash.

**Requires OTX_API_KEY** (free registration at alienvault.com).

Search for pulses (threat reports) in AlienVault OTX.

Pulses are community-contributed threat reports containing
IOCs, context, and references.

**Requires OTX_API_KEY** (free registration at alienvault.com).

post.description:
Create a search/URL monitor.

Monitors periodically check for changes and can trigger webhooks.

get.description: List all search monitors.
Get monitor details and recent results.

post.description:
Configure webhook for a monitor.

When the monitor detects changes, it will POST to the webhook URL.
Optionally verifies the endpoint can receive callbacks.

get.description:
Get the status of an async job.

Returns job metadata and results if completed.

delete.description:
Cancel a pending or running job.

Cannot cancel completed jobs.

get.description:
Stream results from multiple search queries using SSE.

Executes multiple search queries sequentially and streams results
for each query as they become available.

Query parameter should be comma-separated list of queries.
Example: ?q=python tutorial,javascript basics,rust programming

post.description:
Track a new cryptocurrency wallet.

Validates the address format and adds it to the tracking list.
Returns existing wallet if address is already tracked.

**Supported Networks:** BTC, ETH, LTC, DOGE

get.description: List all tracked wallets.
Get wallet details by ID.

Get live balance from blockchain.

Fetches current balance from public blockchain APIs:
- BTC/LTC/DOGE: BlockCypher API
- ETH: Etherscan API

Get transaction history from blockchain.

Fetches recent transactions from public blockchain APIs.
Results are paginated.
List supported cryptocurrency networks.

Forward DNS lookups.

Search DNS A/AAAA records by hostname, IP, or nameserver.
Use summarize to get aggregated results (e.g., all IPs for a host).

Reverse DNS (PTR) lookups.

Get PTR records for an IP or search by PTR hostname.
MX record lookups.
TXT record lookups (SPF, DKIM, DMARC, etc.).

Domain WHOIS lookup.

Returns registrant info, nameservers, dates, and registration details.

Reverse WHOIS search.

Find domains by registrant name, email, phone, or other WHOIS fields.
Useful for finding related domains owned by same entity.

Comprehensive domain intelligence.

Combines WHOIS, DNS, MX, TXT, and certificate data for full picture.

IP WHOIS lookup.

Returns network block, organization, registry, and allocation dates.

Quick IP summary.

Returns primary entity name and associated domain.

Get abuse contact for IP.

Returns abuse email addresses from WHOIS and/or BGP data.

BGP/Prefix WHOIS.

Returns AS information, organization, and CIDR allocations.

BGP routing information.

Returns BGP routes and AS path information.

Reverse IP WHOIS search.

Find IP ranges by organization name, domain, email, or address.

Comprehensive IP intelligence.

Combines WHOIS, BGP, abuse contacts, and port scan data.

Protocol scan data.

Search for hosts by IP, server software, titles, headers, etc.

Open ports summary.

Returns port counts and honeypot detection for IP.

Domain/vhost scan data.

Search for virtual hosts and domain scan results.

JARM fingerprint lookups.

JARM is a TLS fingerprinting technique for identifying servers.
Useful for tracking C2 infrastructure.

Favicon hash lookups.

Find IPs/hosts by favicon hash. Useful for tracking related infrastructure.

Certificate Transparency log searches.

Search CT logs for certificates by domain, organization, or IP.
Use prefix=true for wildcard subdomain enumeration.

Enumerate subdomains using CT logs and DNS.

Combines multiple sources for comprehensive subdomain discovery.

Multi-facet summary across data types.

Returns enrichments and observations organized by type.
Provides a quick overview of all data related to a target.

CVE information lookup.

Returns CVSS score, descriptions, EPSS score, KEV status, and references.
Domain autocomplete suggestions.
Scan value autocomplete suggestions.

List all loaded rulesets.

Optionally filter by target domain.

post.description:
Create a new ruleset.

You can provide either:
- `yaml_content`: Raw YAML to parse
- `rule_groups`: Structured rule groups

Returns the created ruleset with its ID.

get.description:
Get a ruleset by ID.

Returns the full ruleset including all rule groups.

put.description:
Update a ruleset.

Only provided fields will be updated.

post.description:
Validate YAML content without loading.

Returns validation status, errors, and warnings.

Test a ruleset against a URL.

Fetches the URL, applies matching rules, and returns extracted data.

Find all rulesets that match a URL.

Useful for debugging which rules will apply to a given URL.

get.description: List recent events from the event bus history.
Get event bus statistics.

post.description: Manually emit an event (admin/testing).

get.description: List all triggers.

post.description: Create a new trigger.

get.description: Get trigger by ID.

post.description: Test a trigger against mock event data.

get.description:
List all loaded plugins.

Returns plugin name, version, description, and enabled status.
Get detailed information about a plugin.

post.description: Enable a disabled plugin.
Disable a plugin without unloading it.
Reload a specific plugin.
Reload all plugins.

Load a new plugin from a file path.

Note: This loads from the server's filesystem.

Perform a comprehensive vulnerability scan.

Includes:
- Port scanning (TCP)
- Service/version detection
- CVE matching for detected services
- Security header analysis (if web ports open)
- TLS configuration check

**Scan Types:**
- `quick`: Top 100 ports (fastest)
- `standard`: Top 1000 ports
- `comprehensive`: All 65535 ports (slowest)

**Note:** Scanning requires network access to the target.
Only scan systems you have permission to test.

Perform port scan only (no CVE matching).

Faster than full vulnerability scan.
Returns open ports with service detection.

get.description:
Search for CVEs.

Examples:
- `/v1/vuln/cve/search?product=nginx&version=1.18`
- `/v1/vuln/cve/search?keyword=log4j&severity=critical`

Get details for a specific CVE.

Example: GET /v1/vuln/cve/CVE-2023-44487

Quick check if a single port is open.

Useful for testing connectivity before full scan.

List available AI agents.

Returns information about each agent type including:
- Description of what the agent does
- Available tools the agent can use

List all tools available to agents.

Tools are API endpoints that agents can call to gather information.

post.description:
Run an AI agent task.

**Agent Types:**
- `research` - Multi-source information gathering
- `analysis` - Pattern recognition and correlation
- `threat_hunter` - Security threat investigation
- `report` - Generate structured reports

**Async Mode (default):**
Returns immediately with task_id. Use GET /v1/agents/tasks/{id} to check status.

**Sync Mode:**
Waits for completion and returns result directly (may timeout for long tasks).

**Example:**
```json
{
  "task": "Research the security posture of example.com",
  "async_mode": true
}
```

get.description:
List agent tasks.

Filter by status or agent type.

Get agent task status and result.

Returns full task details including:
- Current status
- Result (if completed)
- Steps taken by the agent
- Error details (if failed)

post.description:
Cancel a running agent task.

Only running tasks can be cancelled.

get.description:
List all supported Sigma backends.

Returns backend identifiers, names, descriptions, and supported pipelines.

Supported backends include:
- splunk: Splunk SPL
- elasticsearch: Elasticsearch Lucene/DSL
- qradar: IBM QRadar AQL
- microsoft_sentinel: Azure Sentinel KQL
- And more...

post.description:
Validate a Sigma rule.

Checks for:
- Valid YAML syntax
- Required fields (title, logsource, detection)
- Detection condition syntax
- Modifier validity

Example request:
```yaml
title: Suspicious PowerShell
logsource:
    category: process_creation
    product: windows
detection:
    selection:
        CommandLine|contains: 'powershell'
    condition: selection
level: high
```

Returns validation result with errors and warnings.

Convert a Sigma rule to a backend query language.

Example request:
```json
{
    "rule": "title: Test\nlogsource:\n  category: test\ndetection:\n  sel:\n    field: value\n  condition: sel",
    "backend": "splunk",
    "pipeline": "windows"
}
```

Supported backends:
- splunk: Splunk SPL
- elasticsearch: Elasticsearch Lucene
- qradar: IBM QRadar AQL
- microsoft_sentinel: Azure KQL

Returns the converted query ready for the target SIEM.

Parse a Sigma rule and extract metadata.

Returns:
- Rule title, ID, description
- Author and dates
- Severity level
- MITRE ATT&CK tags
- Log source configuration
- Detection logic

Useful for cataloging and analyzing rule collections.

Match a Sigma rule against log events.

Tests the rule detection logic against provided log entries.
Useful for:
- Testing rules before deployment
- Validating detection coverage
- Debugging false positives/negatives

Example request:
```json
{
    "rule": "...",
    "logs": [
        {"CommandLine": "powershell -enc ...", "User": "admin"},
        {"CommandLine": "notepad.exe", "User": "user"}
    ]
}
```

Returns matching logs with rule information.

get.description:
Get YARA service information.

Returns:
- YARA library version
- Availability status
- Configuration limits
- Supported features

post.description:
Validate a YARA rule.

Checks for:
- Valid YARA syntax
- Proper string definitions
- Valid condition expressions
- Undefined variable references

Example rule:
```
rule SuspiciousFile
{
    meta:
        description = "Detects suspicious patterns"

    strings:
        $s1 = "malicious"
        $s2 = { 4D 5A }  // MZ header

    condition:
        $s1 or $s2
}
```

Returns validation result with errors.

Compile a YARA rule.

Validates and compiles the rule, returning:
- Compilation status
- Rule names found
- Any errors or warnings

External variables can be provided for rules that use them:
```json
{
    "rule": "rule Test { condition: filename matches /\.exe$/ }",
    "externals": {"filename": "test.exe"}
}
```

Scan data with a YARA rule.

Data can be provided as:
- Plain text (encoding: "text")
- Base64-encoded binary (encoding: "base64")

Example request:
```json
{
    "rule": "rule Test { strings: $a = \"test\" condition: $a }",
    "data": "This is a test string",
    "encoding": "text",
    "include_offsets": true
}
```

Returns matched rules with:
- Rule name and metadata
- Matched strings with offsets
- Scan statistics

Fetch URL content and scan with YARA rule.

Fetches the URL content and scans it for pattern matches.
Useful for scanning web pages, downloads, or remote files.

Example request:
```json
{
    "rule": "rule EmailPattern { strings: $email = /[a-z]+@[a-z]+\.[a-z]+/ condition: $email }",
    "url": "https://example.com/page.html"
}
```

Returns scan results with matches found in the URL content.

Fuzz directories and paths on a target URL.

Similar to wfuzz/dirb/gobuster, this endpoint tests for common
directories and files that may be exposed on a web server.

**Wordlists**: Use built-in wordlists or provide custom paths.
- `common`: Common directories and files
- `dirs`: Directory names only
- `files`: Common file names
- `api`: Common API endpoints

**WARNING**: Only use against systems you own or have explicit
permission to test. Unauthorized scanning is illegal.

get.description:
List available built-in wordlists.

Returns wordlist names, descriptions, and entry counts.

post.description:
Fuzz URL or form parameters with payloads.

Tests parameters with various payloads to discover vulnerabilities
or interesting behavior.

**Payload sets**: Use built-in payloads or provide custom values.
- `xss`: Cross-site scripting payloads
- `sqli`: SQL injection payloads
- `lfi`: Local file inclusion payloads
- `traversal`: Path traversal payloads

Use `"FUZZ"` as a parameter value to replace with payload set.

**WARNING**: Only use against systems you own or have explicit
permission to test.

get.description:
List available built-in payload sets.

Returns payload set names, descriptions, and counts.

Scan security headers for a URL.

Checks for important security headers:
- Content-Security-Policy
- Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS)
- X-Content-Type-Options
- X-Frame-Options
- X-XSS-Protection
- Referrer-Policy
- Permissions-Policy

Returns a security score and letter grade.

post.description:
Scan for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities.

Tests URL parameters with XSS payloads and checks if they are
reflected in the response without proper encoding.

**WARNING**: Only scan systems you have permission to test.

Scan for SQL Injection vulnerabilities.

Tests URL parameters with SQL injection payloads and checks
for database error messages in responses.

**WARNING**: Only scan systems you have permission to test.

Scan for Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerabilities.

Tests URL parameters with path traversal payloads and checks
for sensitive file content in responses.

**WARNING**: Only scan systems you have permission to test.

Run full vulnerability scan.

Combines multiple security checks:
- Security headers analysis
- XSS vulnerability testing
- SQL injection testing
- Local file inclusion testing

Specify `checks` in request body to limit which tests run:
`["headers", "xss", "sqli", "lfi"]`

**WARNING**: Only scan systems you have permission to test.
Full scans can generate significant traffic.

Start a web crawl job with human behavior simulation.

Recursively crawls a website following links based on the specified mode:
- **single**: Only crawl the starting URL
- **domain**: Stay within the same domain (allows subdomains)
- **subdomain**: Stay within the exact subdomain
- **recursive**: Follow all links (use with caution)

Browsing modes control anti-detection behavior:
- **fast**: Minimal delays, direct navigation
- **normal**: Standard human-like delays
- **human**: Full simulation (mouse, scroll, typing delays)
- **stealth**: Maximum anti-detection, slowest
- **amazon**: Special mode for heavily protected sites (requires residential proxy)

**IMPORTANT**: Sites like Amazon, Nike block datacenter IPs. You MUST provide
a residential proxy in the `proxy` field to crawl these sites successfully.

**WARNING**: Only crawl sites you own or have permission to access.

**Example (basic):**
```json
{
    "url": "https://example.com",
    "mode": "domain",
    "browsing_mode": "human",
    "max_depth": 2,
    "max_pages": 20
}
```

**Example (with residential proxy for Amazon):**
```json
{
    "url": "https://www.amazon.com/s?k=shoes",
    "mode": "single",
    "browsing_mode": "amazon",
    "proxy": {
        "server": "http://residential.proxy.com:8080",
        "username": "user",
        "password": "pass"
    }
}
```

Crawl a single page with full JavaScript rendering.

Uses Camoufox (anti-detect Firefox) with human behavior simulation
to render the page, extract content, and optionally capture screenshot.

**Browsing modes:**
- **fast**: Minimal delays (0.1-0.3s)
- **normal**: Standard delays (0.5-1.5s)
- **human**: Full HBS - mouse, scroll, typing (1.5-4s)
- **stealth**: Maximum anti-detection (3-7s)
- **amazon**: For heavily protected sites (2-5s, requires proxy)

**IMPORTANT**: Sites like Amazon, Nike block datacenter IPs. Use a residential
proxy in the `proxy` field to crawl these sites successfully.

Returns:
- Page title and final URL (after redirects)
- Extracted text content
- All discovered links and images
- Page metadata (meta tags, canonical, language)
- Optional screenshot path

**Example (basic):**
```json
{
    "url": "https://example.com/page",
    "browsing_mode": "human",
    "extract_content": true
}
```

**Example (with proxy for Amazon):**
```json
{
    "url": "https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09V3KXJPB",
    "browsing_mode": "amazon",
    "proxy": {
        "server": "http://residential.proxy.com:8080",
        "username": "user",
        "password": "pass"
    }
}
```

get.description:
List available crawl and browsing modes.

Returns descriptions of each mode to help choose the right configuration.

post.description:
Capture all XHR/fetch network requests from a webpage.

Intercepts all API calls made during page load and interaction.
Useful for reverse engineering how a website fetches its data.

**Features:**
- Captures XHR and fetch requests
- Records request/response headers and bodies
- Identifies JSON/GraphQL endpoints
- Detects authentication headers
- Scrolls page to trigger lazy loading
- Can click elements to trigger more API calls

**Example (basic):**
```json
{
  "url": "https://example.com",
  "wait_time": 5.0,
  "scroll": true
}
```

**Example (with clicks to trigger API calls):**
```json
{
  "url": "https://example.com/movies",
  "wait_time": 8.0,
  "click_selectors": [".load-more", ".show-times-btn", "button.details"],
  "filter_patterns": ["api", "graphql", "json"]
}
```

**Returns:**
- List of discovered API endpoints
- Request/response details for each
- Authentication headers found
- WebSocket URLs
- Cookies set

Analyze captured API endpoints to understand the API structure.

Takes a list of captured endpoints and returns:
- Summary statistics
- Categorization (REST vs GraphQL)
- Authentication methods detected
- Common patterns

Typically used after `/capture` to analyze results.

Export captured network traffic to HAR (HTTP Archive) format.

HAR files can be:
- Imported into browser DevTools for replay
- Analyzed with HAR viewers
- Converted to other formats
- Used for performance analysis

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],  // From /capture response
  "page_url": "https://example.com",
  "page_title": "Example Site"
}
```

Generate OpenAPI 3.0 specification from captured traffic.

Auto-generates:
- Path operations with parameters
- Request/response schemas (inferred from JSON)
- Authentication schemes
- Tags from URL structure

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],
  "title": "Cineplex API",
  "description": "Unofficial API reverse engineered from cineplex.com",
  "infer_schemas": true
}
```

**Use cases:**
- Generate API documentation
- Create client SDKs
- Build mock servers
- Test API compatibility

Generate Postman Collection v2.1 from captured traffic.

Creates an importable Postman collection with:
- All captured requests
- Headers and query parameters
- Request bodies
- Sample responses

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],
  "name": "Cineplex API Collection",
  "description": "Captured from cineplex.com"
}
```

Import the result directly into Postman for testing.

Generate Insomnia Export v4 from captured traffic.

Creates an importable Insomnia collection with:
- Workspace containing all requests
- Organized folders by API path
- Headers and query parameters
- Request bodies
- Base environment with base_url variable

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],
  "name": "CoinGecko API",
  "description": "Captured from coingecko.com"
}
```

Import via Insomnia: Application > Preferences > Data > Import Data.

Attempt GraphQL schema introspection.

Sends an introspection query to discover:
- All types (Query, Mutation, Subscription)
- Fields and arguments
- Input types
- Enums and interfaces

**Note:** Many production GraphQL APIs disable introspection.

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoint_url": "https://api.example.com/graphql",
  "headers": {"Authorization": "Bearer token123"}
}
```

Detect authentication methods from captured requests.

Analyzes request headers and parameters to identify:
- Bearer tokens
- API keys (header or query)
- Basic auth
- CSRF tokens
- OAuth tokens

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...]
}
```

Infer JSON Schema from sample data.

Uses GenSON to analyze JSON samples and generate a schema that:
- Captures the structure of all samples
- Identifies required vs optional fields
- Detects data types
- Handles arrays and nested objects

**Example:**
```json
{
  "samples": [
    {"name": "John", "age": 30},
    {"name": "Jane", "age": 25, "email": "jane@example.com"}
  ]
}
```

Capture WebSocket messages from a webpage.

Intercepts all WebSocket connections and logs:
- Connection URLs
- All sent and received messages
- Binary and text frames
- Connection lifecycle events

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://trading-app.com",
  "wait_time": 15,
  "interact": true
}
```

Use for reverse engineering real-time APIs (chat, trading, live data).

Replay a captured API request.

Re-sends the request and optionally compares with original response.

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://api.example.com/users",
  "method": "GET",
  "headers": {"Authorization": "Bearer token"},
  "original_response": {"status": 200, "body": "..."}
}
```

Replay multiple captured endpoints concurrently.

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],
  "concurrency": 5
}
```

Fuzz an endpoint with security payloads.

Tests for common vulnerabilities:
- SQL Injection
- XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)
- Path Traversal
- Authentication Bypass
- IDOR (Insecure Direct Object Reference)

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://api.example.com/users?id=1",
  "fuzz_types": ["sql_injection", "idor"]
}
```

**Warning:** Only test endpoints you have authorization to test.

Test an endpoint for authentication bypass vulnerabilities.

Tests:
- Removing auth headers
- Empty auth values
- Default/common tokens
- Null/undefined values

**Warning:** Only test endpoints you have authorization to test.

Compare two OpenAPI specifications and detect changes.

Identifies:
- Added/removed endpoints
- Breaking changes (required params, type changes)
- Non-breaking changes (new optional params)
- Schema modifications

**Example:**
```json
{
  "old_spec": {"openapi": "3.0.0", ...},
  "new_spec": {"openapi": "3.0.0", ...}
}
```

Automatically discover hidden API endpoints.

Uses intelligent heuristics to:
- Click buttons and interactive elements
- Fill and submit forms
- Scroll to trigger lazy loading
- Follow internal links
- Detect dynamic content

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://webapp.example.com",
  "max_interactions": 50,
  "fill_forms": true
}
```

Returns all discovered API endpoints from interactions.

Generate a mock server from captured traffic.

Creates runnable server code that replays captured responses.

**Server Types:**
- `fastapi`: Python FastAPI server
- `express`: Node.js Express server

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],
  "name": "Cineplex Mock API",
  "server_type": "fastapi"
}
```

Returns server code ready to run.

Generate executable commands from captured API endpoints.

**Supported Formats:**
- `curl`: cURL command line
- `httpie`: HTTPie command line
- `python`: Python requests code
- `javascript`: JavaScript fetch code
- `powershell`: PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest
- `all`: All formats

**Example:**
```json
{
  "endpoints": [...],
  "format": "curl",
  "include_headers": true
}
```

**Use cases:**
- Quick API testing from terminal
- Sharing requests with teammates
- Debugging and reproduction
- Documentation examples

Start a proxy capture session.

Starts an HTTP proxy server that captures all traffic flowing through it.
Configure your device/app to use this proxy to capture traffic.

**Steps:**
1. Start proxy with this endpoint
2. Configure your device to use the proxy (see /proxy/instructions)
3. Use your app normally
4. Stop proxy and retrieve captured traffic

**Example:**
```json
{
  "port": 8888,
  "filter_hosts": ["api.example.com"],
  "exclude_hosts": ["analytics.google.com"]
}
```

**Note:** For HTTPS, you may need to install the proxy's CA certificate.

Stop the active proxy capture session.

Returns the captured traffic and session summary.

get.description:
Get the status of the active proxy session.

Returns session info and current flow count.

Get captured traffic from a proxy session.

Args:
    session_id: Session ID (uses active session if not provided)
    as_endpoints: Return in standard endpoint format (default: true)

Get instructions for configuring proxy on different platforms.

Returns setup instructions for macOS, Windows, Linux, iOS, Android,
and example code for curl and Python.

post.description:
Create a new API monitor.

Monitors an API for changes over time:
- New/removed endpoints
- Schema changes
- Status code changes
- Response time degradation

**Example:**
```json
{
  "name": "Cineplex API",
  "url": "https://cineplex.com",
  "interval_minutes": 60,
  "alert_webhook": "https://slack.com/webhook/..."
}
```

get.description:
List all API monitors.

Returns all configured monitors with their status.

Get details for a specific monitor.

Returns monitor configuration and recent changes.

delete.description:
Delete an API monitor.

Removes the monitor and all its snapshots/history.

post.description:
Manually trigger a snapshot capture for a monitor.

Captures current state and compares with previous snapshot.

Compare two OpenAPI specs and detect changes.

Useful for comparing specs from different sources or time periods.

**Detects:**
- Added/removed endpoints
- Schema changes
- Breaking changes

Discover API endpoints on a website.

Probes common API patterns including:
- REST APIs (/api, /api/v1, /rest)
- JSON:API (Drupal)
- WordPress REST API
- GraphQL endpoints
- RSS/Atom feeds

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://example.gov",
  "cms_hint": "drupal"
}
```

**Returns:**
- List of discovered API endpoints with type, status, and sample response

Detect the CMS or framework used by a website.

Detects:
- Drupal (via headers, HTML patterns, /jsonapi)
- WordPress (via /wp-json, /wp-content)
- Next.js (via __NEXT_DATA__, /_next)
- Nuxt.js (via __NUXT__, /_nuxt)
- Shopify (via CDN, headers)
- And more...

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://www.mass.gov"
}
```

**Returns:**
- CMS type, version (if detected), confidence score, and indicators

Extract embedded JSON/data from HTML page.

Extracts:
- Drupal settings (data-drupal-selector)
- JSON-LD structured data
- Next.js __NEXT_DATA__
- Nuxt.js __NUXT__
- Redux/Vuex initial state
- Apollo GraphQL state

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://www.mass.gov/some-page"
}
```

**Returns:**
- List of embedded data blocks with type and parsed content

Explore a JSON:API endpoint (Drupal-style).

JSON:API is a specification used by Drupal 8+ and other frameworks.
This endpoint discovers available resource types and suggests filters.

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://www.mass.gov",
  "search_term": "media"
}
```

**Returns:**
- List of available resource types (node, media, taxonomy, etc.)
- Suggested filter queries for common operations

Search a website's sitemap for URLs matching a pattern.

Automatically finds sitemap.xml and searches across all pages.
Supports sitemap indexes (multiple sitemaps).

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://www.mass.gov",
  "pattern": "breach.*pdf",
  "limit": 50
}
```

**Returns:**
- Sitemap URL found
- Total URLs in sitemap
- URLs matching the pattern

Perform full reconnaissance on a website.

Combines all recon capabilities:
1. CMS/Framework detection
2. API endpoint discovery
3. Embedded data extraction
4. JSON:API exploration (if Drupal)
5. Sitemap search (if goal provided)

**Example:**
```json
{
  "url": "https://www.mass.gov",
  "goal": "find breach notification data"
}
```

**Returns:**
- Complete analysis including CMS, APIs, feeds, embedded data
- Recommendations for accessing data based on findings

Create a paste site monitor.

Monitors Pastebin, GitHub Gists, and other paste sites for:
- Keywords
- Domain patterns (company domains)
- Credential leaks (AWS keys, API tokens, passwords)

get.description: List all paste monitors.

post.description: Run a paste monitor check now.

One-time search across paste sites.

Search for:
- Keywords
- Domain patterns
- Email patterns
- Credentials (auto-detected)

get.description: Get list of built-in credential detection patterns.

List all tracked ransomware groups.

Data sourced from RansomLook and Ransomwatch.

parameters.name: status

schema.description: Filter by status: active, inactive, defunct
schema.title: Status

parameters.description: Filter by status: active, inactive, defunct

get.description:
List recent ransomware victim announcements.

Returns victims from the last N days.

post.description:
Search ransomware victim database.

Search by company name, domain, group, etc.

get.description:
Check if a domain appears in ransomware victim lists.

Use for supply chain risk assessment.
Get ransomware statistics and trends.

post.description:
Create a tracker to monitor for specific victims.

Alerts when companies/domains matching your patterns appear.

get.description: List all ransomware trackers.

post.description: Run a ransomware tracker check now.

Add a forum to monitor.

Supports both clearnet and .onion URLs.
Uses Tor proxy for .onion sites.

get.description: List all configured forums.

post.description:
Capture a snapshot of a forum.

Crawls the forum and extracts posts.

Create a forum monitor.

Monitors configured forums for keywords, patterns, and authors.

get.description: List all forum monitors.

post.description: Run a forum monitor check now.

get.description: Get CSS selector templates for common forum software.

List tracked ransomware sites.

Returns all known ransomware leak sites with their current status.
Data sourced from ransomwatch and other pluggable sources.

parameters.name: status

schema.description: Filter by status: online, offline, unknown
schema.title: Status

parameters.description: Filter by status: online, offline, unknown

get.description:
Get ransomware site statistics.

Returns aggregate statistics including:
- Total tracked sites
- Online/offline counts
- Sites by group
- Historical uptime data

List available data sources for ransomware sites.

Returns all registered sources with their status.
Sources can be enabled/disabled dynamically.

List ransomware groups with their statistics.

Returns per-group statistics including site counts and uptime.

Stream ransomware site status changes via SSE.

Emits events when site status changes (online/offline).
Connect with EventSource API for real-time updates.

Get details for a specific ransomware site.

Returns site info, current status, and status history.

post.description:
Check a ransomware site's current status.

Probes the site via Tor and returns:
- Online/offline status
- Response time
- Captcha detection
- JavaScript requirements

Scrape content from an .onion site via Tor.

Uses aiohttp-socks for reliable Tor connections (not browser-based).
Returns:
- HTML content and extracted text
- Page title and metadata
- All links and images found
- Captcha/JS detection
- Extracted leak data patterns (dates, file sizes, victim entries)

This is more reliable than browser-based scraping for .onion sites.

Scrape multiple .onion sites and compare with upstream data.

Features:
- Scrapes sites in parallel with rate limiting
- Extracts victim/company data from HTML
- Compares scraped data with upstream feeds (ransomwatch, etc.)
- Identifies new victims not yet in upstream sources

Returns scrape results, extracted victims, and upstream comparison.

Extract victim data from HTML content.

Parses HTML using group-specific patterns to extract:
- Company names
- Websites/domains
- Countries
- Data sizes
- Publication dates

Capture a screenshot of an .onion site via Tor.

Uses Camoufox browser to render and capture the full page.
Screenshots are saved to /app/data/screenshots/ directory.

Returns the screenshot file path and metadata.

Capture screenshots of multiple .onion sites.

Processes sites in parallel with concurrency limits to avoid
overwhelming Tor network. Returns paths to all captured screenshots.

Detect if a site's content has changed since last check.

Compares content hash with stored hash. If changed:
- Records the change in history
- Emits SSE event for real-time alerts
- Stores new hash for future comparison

First check establishes baseline (no change detection).

Check multiple sites for content changes.

Returns summary of:
- Sites that changed (with diff info)
- Sites unchanged
- First-time checks (baseline established)
- Failed checks

Use this for periodic monitoring of ransomware leak sites.

get.description:
Get change history for a specific site.

Returns chronological list of all detected changes including:
- Old and new content hashes
- Timestamps of changes
- Content length differences

Get all recent content changes across monitored sites.

Returns chronologically sorted list of recent changes
detected across all ransomware leak sites being monitored.

Useful for alerting dashboards and monitoring.

post.description:
Refresh status for ransomware sites.

Checks site availability in bulk. Returns summary statistics.
Limited to prevent overwhelming Tor network.

parameters.name: group

schema.description: Refresh only sites from this group
schema.title: Group

parameters.description: Refresh only sites from this group

get.description:
List recent ransomware victims/breaches.

Returns companies that have been claimed by ransomware groups
on their leak sites. Data sourced from ransomwatch and ransomlook.

parameters.name: days

schema.description: Only victims from last N days
schema.title: Days

parameters.description: Only victims from last N days

get.description:
Get ransomware victim statistics.

Returns aggregate statistics including:
- Total victims in period
- Top ransomware groups by victim count
- Daily victim counts

Search ransomware victims by company name.

Search across victim/breach data to find if a specific
company has been targeted by ransomware groups.

Export ALL .onion ransomware site URLs.

Returns a complete list of ransomware leak site .onion addresses
aggregated from all sources. Use this to build your own database.

Formats:
- json: Full data with group, domain, url, available status
- csv: Comma-separated for spreadsheets
- txt: Just the URLs, one per line

parameters.name: format

schema.description: Export format: json, csv, or txt
schema.title: Format

post.description:
Sync ALL ransomware data from upstream sources to LOCAL storage.

This pulls all sites and victims from ransomware.live, ransomwatch,
and ransomlook, then stores them permanently in Valkey.

After sync, you OWN the data - no dependency on external sources.

get.description:
Check what's NEW in upstream sources vs our local database.

Compares local Valkey data with ransomware.live, ransomwatch, ransomlook
and shows what URLs/victims we're MISSING locally.

Does NOT modify local data - just shows the diff.

post.description:
Check upstream for NEW URLs and MERGE them into local database.

1. Checks ransomware.live, ransomwatch, ransomlook
2. Finds URLs/victims we don't have locally
3. Appends them to our local Valkey database

Only adds NEW data - doesn't overwrite existing.

get.description:
Get status of local data sync.

Shows when data was last synced and counts of local sites/victims.

Get ransomware sites from LOCAL storage (not upstream).

Returns sites that were synced to Valkey. No external API calls.

Get ALL .onion URLs from LOCAL storage.

These are YOUR locally stored URLs - no external dependency.
Must run /sync first to populate local storage.

get.description:
Get ransomware victims from LOCAL storage.

Returns victims that were synced to Valkey. No external API calls.

List all raw data feed URLs for ransomware intelligence.

Returns the upstream sources where we pull ransomware site data from.
You can use these URLs directly to build your own database.

List all tracked Telegram channels.

Supports filtering by:
- Category (ransomware, data_leaks, hacking_tools, etc.)
- Risk level (low, medium, high, critical)
- Tags
- Search query
- Associated threat actor

Returns channels sorted by risk level (critical first).

post.description:
Add a new channel to track.

Required fields:
- username: Telegram username (without @)
- title: Display name

Optional fields:
- category: Type of channel (ransomware, data_leaks, etc.)
- threat_actor: Associated threat actor/group
- risk_level: low, medium, high, critical
- tags: List of tags

get.description:
Full-text search across all channel fields.

Searches in:
- Username
- Title
- Description
- Threat actor name
- Tags

Returns results ranked by relevance.

Get details for a specific channel.

Returns full channel metadata including:
- Category and tags
- Associated threat actor
- Risk level
- Member count (if available)
- Direct URL to channel

patch.description:
Update a channel's metadata.

All fields are optional - only provided fields will be updated.

get.description:
List all channel categories with counts.

Categories include:
- ransomware: Ransomware operator channels
- data_leaks: Data breach marketplaces
- hacking_tools: Hacking tools and utilities
- malware: Malware samples and development
- stealer_logs: Infostealer logs
- initial_access: Initial access brokers
- apt_groups: APT group channels
- hacktivism: Hacktivist groups
- And more...

Get overall statistics.

Returns:
- Total channels tracked
- Breakdown by category
- Breakdown by risk level
- Breakdown by country
- List of tracked threat actors
List all tracked threat actors with their channels.

post.description:
Sync channels from external threat intel sources.

Currently syncs from:
- ransomware.live Telegram data

Adds new channels and updates member counts for existing ones.

get.description: List available external data sources.

Export channels in various formats.

Formats:
- json: Full JSON export
- csv: CSV file with basic fields
- urls: Plain list of t.me URLs
Quick access to all ransomware group channels.
Quick access to all data leak/breach channels.

Quick access to all stealer log channels.

These channels sell/share credentials stolen by infostealers
like RedLine, Raccoon, Vidar, etc.
Quick access to all hacktivist group channels.

Quick access to all critical-risk channels.

These are the highest-priority channels to monitor.

post.description:
Generate a Scrapy spider for a target URL.

Uses site analysis and API discovery to select the best template,
then runs TDD cycle to produce working code.

Returns:
    - spider_code: Generated spider Python code
    - test_code: Generated pytest code
    - tdd_report: TDD execution report

Analyze a website's structure and protection.

Returns:
    - structure: Page structure (table, list, api_driven)
    - protection: Detected protection (cloudflare, captcha)
    - selectors: Inferred CSS/XPath selectors
    - pagination: Pagination detection results
    - apis_found: Discovered API endpoints (if discover_apis=true)

get.description:
List available spider templates.

Returns descriptions and use cases for each template type.

post.description:
Validate spider code syntax without executing.

Returns:
    - valid: Whether code has valid Python syntax
    - error: Syntax error message if invalid

Run pytest on spider and test code.

Returns:
    - passed: Whether all tests passed
    - errors: List of error messages
    - output: Full pytest output

Quick spider generation without full TDD cycle.

Faster but may produce less tested code.
Use /generate for production-quality spiders.

If config.spider_type is specified (not "auto"), uses that template directly.

get.description: Check spider generator service health.

post.description:
**DEPRECATED**: Use `/v1/breaches/spider/parallel` instead.

Legacy spider endpoint. The parallel endpoint with Webshare proxy
support is the recommended approach for extraction.

get.description: Get current spider run status (running, completed, failed).

Get collected breach records with optional filtering.

Records are sorted by reported_date (newest first).
Get statistics from last spider run.
Export all collected records as JSON or CSV download.

post.description:
Run parallel breach extraction using Camoufox browsers.

**Recommended endpoint** for extracting breach records from the
Data Breach Chronology database (90,000+ records).

**How it works:**
- Workers partition by state/org_type/search (zero overlap on states)
- Multiple browser instances work in parallel
- 100 residential proxies auto-rotate every ~4K records (before 5K rate limit)
- On 429 error, automatically rotates to next proxy

**Strategies (recommended order):**
- `states`: 53 states + UNKN broken by org_type (60 partitions, recommended)
- `org_types`: 7 partitions by organization type
- `states_and_types`: 385 partitions (state x org_type full grid)
- `full`: States + UNKN breakdown + search terms (maximum coverage)
- `search`: 159 search terms (legacy, has overlap)
- `search_extended`: 360+ searches (adds letter combinations)

**Proxy Rotation:**
- Auto-detects `Webshare 100 proxies.txt` (100 residential IPs)
- Proactive rotation at 4K records per proxy
- 100 proxies x 5K = 500K capacity (only need 90K)

Extract ALL 90K+ records from the Breach Chronology database.

**Configuration:**
- Strategy: `full` (states  org_types  search terms)
- Workers: 3 parallel browser instances
- Proxy: Auto-detects `Webshare 100 proxies.txt` (100 residential IPs)
- Rotation: Every ~4K records per proxy (before 5K rate limit)

**Capacity:** 100 proxies x 5K = 500K records (only need 90K)

**Monitor:**
- Status: `GET /v1/breaches/spider/status`
- Records: `GET /v1/breaches/spider/records`
- Export: `GET /v1/breaches/spider/export`

get.description:
Fetch live statistics from the Breach Chronology database.

Opens a browser to get the current record count and organization types.
Requires Camoufox to solve Cloudflare Turnstile.
